Description: Pottery jug in Eastern Sigillata A ware; wheel-made; depressed globular body on a ring base with a narrow concave neck and flat, everted rim; angular vertical handle from shoulder to neck; buff clay with a lustrous red slip, with rouletted incisions on the lower body; slip is eroded in many places, especially in the grooves.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Horatio Herbert Kitchener, Earl Kitchener of Khartoum
Curator's comments: The numbers 22 and 87 [?] pencilled on the vase may refer to the original excavations, but this is uncertain. See Bailey, Op. Ath. VI (1965), pp. 5-13 for details of the Hake-Kitchener excavations. Parallels: SCE IV/3, fig. 31, 10; J. Hayes 1985, Arte Antica, 45-46 (Form 111), citing GR 1894,11-1.512 from Amathus Tomb 143 as the type specimen; C. Abadie-Reynal 1987, 'Céramique romaine', in V. Karageorghis et al. eds, La nécropole d'Amathone Tombs 113-367 II. Céramiques non-Chypriotes (Nicosie), 48 and pl. XXXI, 9, 12 (Tombs 274/6, and 276/2). Several examples from Ayios Ermoyenis also occur in this shape (Tomb 5, unpublished) and 8 (no. 91) and several tombs in the Swedish Tombs at Amathus. An imitation in Cypriot Sigillata was found in Episkopi Tomb 12 (no. 31 and several tombs in Amathus: for details see A. Oliver 1983, 'Tomb 12 at Episkopi', RDAC, 249 (with refs).
Acquisition name: Transferred from: Victoria and Albert Museum
